results.title: Kokoda front line; Herald newsreel
results.brief_description: Two programmes showing historical newsreel footage. 1. “Kokoda front line”. An edition of the weekly news magazine produced by Cinesound consisting of one full-reel coverage by Damien Parer of the war in New Guinea. Winner of an Academy award in 1942. 2. “The Herald newsreel”. One of the first sound films produced in Australia, this newsreel shows Joe Lyons, Primer Minister 1931-1939, and his Cabinet.

results.title: Koko Pops: Koko's history of music
results.creator_credit: Antoinette Starkiewicz, Don Ezard, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A brief and bright animated history of music. Divided into brief vignettes, each with colourful characters dancing and/or playing music, it absorbs the viewer in a mixture of musical styles including primitive, pan flutes, Baroque, romantic, circus music, jazz, French popular, opera and variations of modern music.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Antoinette Starkiewicz, Don Ezard, Robin Hughes and Film Australia

results.title: Koalas: the bare facts
results.creator_credit: Paul Scott, Bruce Moir, Chris Oliver and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Koalas today are a species in trouble, threatened with extinction as the Australian suburbs spread. They are extremely vulnerable because they are dependent on eucalyptus forest and must feed on gum leaves for an average of five hours per day in order to survive. This film takes a dramatic and often amusing look at the plight facing this extraordinary animal and the lengths to which some people will go in order to help. If you think koalas are cute and cuddly animals who just sit round eating gum leaves all day, this film will surprise you.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Scott, Bruce Moir, Chris Oliver and Film Australia

results.title: Koala
results.creator_credit: Harold J. Pollock and Bank of New South Wales
results.brief_description: A study in detail of the koala, a marsupial which inhabits the eastern and southern parts of the Australian continent. Shows mating habits, birth of the young, nurturing in the pouch and its later development outside the physical protection of the mother, though it still remains dependent upon her for survival. The koala is fully protected throughout Australia today but there is still a great need to set aside large areas of forest country to ensure its continued existence.

results.title: Knowledge about language: genre
results.creator_credit: Cilla Ware, Adrienne Jones and Thames Television
results.brief_description: The traditional children’s story of “Little Red Riding Hood” is used here to illustrate the varying genre styles of soap opera, comedy, crime, documentary and horror, with each change in the story revealing the structural, linguistic and visual conventions of the particular genre the story is reflecting at the time.

results.title: Knowing to learn [edited version]
results.creator_credit: Claude Jutra, Marcel Martin and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A far-ranging round-up of all that is new in technology in the classrooms of North America, demonstrating, among other approaches, the new roles of computer, tape recorder and television in the learning process. The film was produced with the assistance of many institutions and individuals in the United States engaged in experiment and research into all forms of education from infancy to adulthood. Edited version.
